entry.title: Do crossword puzzles really keep your brain sharp?
entry.summary:
An elderly person works on a crossword puzzle. These games can help keep the brain engaged‚Äîbut studies show other habits, like exercise and education, play a far greater role in preventing cognitive decline. They‚Äôve long been seen as a way to prevent cognitive decline‚Äîbut experts say the real key to brain health goes far beyond word games.
Ask almost anyone how to stay mentally sharp in old age; chances are someone will bring up crossword puzzles. Alongside Sudoku and word searches, these games have long been seen as ‚Äúworkouts‚Äù for the brain. In fact, a 2020 study published in Frontiers in Human Neuroscience found these kinds of puzzles are among the most frequently engaged-in activities for brain training and cognitive benefits.
But how did this belief become so widespread? A‚Ä¶

entry.title: Follow the divine topography of this Greek pilgrimage for monks
entry.summary:
The Rousanou Monastery was founded in the 14th century and is one of six still in use in the Meteora region. The region of Meteora combines outlandish topography and improbable architecture to divine effect.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As the sun sinks towards the serrated horizon of the distant Pindus Mountains, the assembled congregation grows quiet. There are perhaps 40 people gathered here, each occupying their own smooth knuckle of the lofty outcrop. Some have been present an hour or more, watching the day slowly drain from this extraordinary landscape. Others, such as myself, a matter of minutes ‚Äî fortuitously passing Meteora‚Äôs most celebrated sunset spot as dusk closes in.
It‚Äôs quite the vantage point: all around, thrusting u‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who is General Tso‚Äîand why does he have his own chicken dish?
entry.summary:
This iconic chicken dish was created for an American general‚Äîbut named after a Chinese one. While the entr√©e was originally created in Taiwan, the recipe was actually specifically crafted for American eaters from the very start.
For the past fifty years, few dishes have defined Chinese-American cuisine quite like General Tso‚Äôs chicken. With its glistening, deep-fried crunch and sticky, sweet-savory glaze, it‚Äôs become a staple on takeout menus across the United States.
But the dish was never meant to reflect traditional Chinese cooking. Although it originated in Taiwan, General Tso‚Äôs chicken was purposefully crafted to seduce the American palate from the very beginning.
(Peking duck: the complex history of a Chinese classic.)
The original version of General Tso‚Äôs c‚Ä¶

entry.title: Was Cyrus the Great really a tolerant conqueror?
entry.summary: The Achaemenid kings of Persia ruled between the sixth and fourth centuries B.C., but much of what we know about them today comes from Greek rather than Persian sources. The various Greek authors who wrote about the Persians tended to depict them as decadent and weak-willed, ruled by a series of self-styled great kings. Persian culture was often contrasted with the austerity of Athens and Sparta. The stories of Persian kings that have filtered down through Greek works of philosophy, history, and plays mix firsthand observations with a large dose of fiction and fantasy. It should be remembered that the Greeks saw the might of Persia as a huge threat. For half a century they were engaged in the Greco-Persian wars (499-449 B.C.), fighting to keep that threat at bay, and this enmity shaped how‚Ä¶

entry.title: An insider‚Äôs guide to Nantes
entry.summary:
Set on France‚Äôs Loire river, roughly 30 miles before it meets the Atlantic Ocean, the colourful city of Nantes is a cultural and artistic hub with a whimsical spirit. With contemporary art installations around every corner and several innovative museums, the city's creative side is prominent, while its Breton identity also remains strong ‚Äî in the 15th century, Nantes was the seat of the dukes of Brittany, before the independent kingdom became part of France in 1532.
Even the city‚Äôs industrial past is treated with an artistic reverence ‚Äî on the site of its former shipyards on the √éle de Nantes (an island on the Loire river), you'll find Les Machines de l‚Äô√Æle, a collection of mechanical creations, including a 40ft-tall elephant that carries passengers around the concourse and sprays wat‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why do birds sing so loudly in spring? It‚Äôs the ‚Äòdawn chorus‚Äô
entry.summary:
As spring begins, so does a fresh song at daybreak, unique to the season. Just before the sun rises, birds start singing their melodies, creating a chirpy symphony.¬†
This phenomenon is known as the dawn chorus, and it‚Äôs special for a number of reasons: There are more birds singing at this time of year, and they also sing more often. This energetic burst of birdsong is often louder than usual too. The dawn chorus‚Äô early morning explosion of sounds has even inspired multiple¬†poems¬†and¬†songs.¬†
‚ÄúIt's the epitome of spring,‚Äù says Jordan E. Rutter, an ornithologist at the American Bird Conservancy. After the long and cold winter, ‚Äúall of a sudden you have this influx of so many beautiful birds coming back and singing.‚Äù
This harmony of birdsong at dawn happens during a fundamental ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Dust isn‚Äôt just dirt‚Äîit‚Äôs full of ‚Äòforever chemicals‚Äô
entry.summary:
Dust may seem like a harmless nuisance‚Äîbut experts say those tiny particles that are floating in the air or accumulating in clumps under your couch or on your windowsill may actually cause more harm than you think.
‚ÄúMost people think dust is gross but I don‚Äôt think people associate dust with the potential health harms it may contain,‚Äù says Tasha Stoiber, a senior scientist at the Environmental Working Group. ‚ÄúIt might not be people‚Äôs number one cleaning priority.‚Äù
But it should be high on the list of priorities because dust isn‚Äôt just dirt. It contains a blend of various substances, including dead skin cells, hair fragments, pet dander, clothing and furniture fibers, dust mites, mold and fungi spores, microplastic particles, as well as allergens (such as pollen), bacteria, and so‚Ä¶

entry.title: Americans knew their booze was poisoned‚Äîand drank it anyway
entry.summary:
When bluesman Ishman Bracey poured himself a drink in Jackson, Mississippi, he didn‚Äôt know his luck had just run as dry as the nation‚Äôs taps.
A couple of weeks later, his legs were tingling. With rumors of a polio surge going around, he rushed to the hospital. But it wasn‚Äôt a virus. He‚Äôd been poisoned.
The cause? A government policy that made drinking alcohol not just illegal‚Äîbut lethal.¬†
During Prohibition, not all alcohol was banned ‚Äî¬†just drinkable, non-medicinal alcohol. To prevent bootleggers from repurposing industrial alcohol, the U.S. government launched what it called the ‚ÄúNoble Experiment,‚Äù adding toxic chemicals like methanol and benzene to render it undrinkable. According to a New York Times headline at the time, the government planned to ‚Äúdouble alcohol poison c‚Ä¶

By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Outdoor adventures are full of thrilling, unexpected moments, from wildlife sightings and jaw-dropping views‚Äîto surprise downpours. Being prepared for any weather is key.¬†¬†
‚ÄúWaterproof pants are important because staying dry means staying warm,‚Äù says Jonathan Grenier, founder of Ungava Polar Eco-Tours, an ecotourism company based in sub-Arctic Quebec. When guiding groups, Grenier often spends long hours trekking or boating in unpredictable condition‚Ä¶

entry.title: How this sleepy Southern town became an art lover's paradise
entry.summary:
Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art was designed by renowned architect Moshe Safdie. With a world-class art museum, 70 miles of hiking and biking trails, and a thriving culinary scene, Bentonville, Arkansas, has emerged as a must-visit family-friendly getaway.
Bentonville, Arkansas, has emerged as a lively artistic and culinary destination, driven by the influence of the renowned Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art. Thanks to this cultural influx, and with plenty to capture the attention of parents and children alike, it's also a perfect getaway for families.
This area has long been known as a masterpiece of wild, wooded beauty. Situated on a plateau among the Ozark Mountains, Bentonville‚Äôs network of nearly 70 miles of trails within the city connect to 400 miles of moun‚Ä¶

entry.title: How a penguin 'massacre' led to new protections in Argentina
entry.summary:
As spring turns to summer in the southern hemisphere, the Punta Tombo Natural Protected Area on Argentina‚Äôs central coast comes alive, with the chicks of some 180,000 pairs of nesting Magellanic penguins braying and peeping 24/7.
That penguin-palooza was nearing a crescendo in November 2021 when tragedy struck. A local rancher named Ricardo La Regina, then 33, intentionally drove a backhoe through nesting grounds just north of Punta Tombo, home to the world‚Äôs second-largest Magellanic penguin colony and part of the UNESCO‚Äôs Patagonia Azul Biosphere Reserve. An estimated 175 nests were crushed and more than 100 penguins killed in what the Argentine press dubbed the ‚ÄúPunta Tombo Penguin Massacre.‚Äù
But after a historic court case, some surprising good has come from the disaster, inc‚Ä¶

entry.title: How winemakers of color are changing South Africa's wine scene
entry.summary:
South African winemakers are ringing in a new dawn for local viniculture. South Africa‚Äôs winemakers of colour are changing the country‚Äôs viticulture, creating a crop of bold new brands.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Pick up almost any bottle of South African wine, and it‚Äôs unlikely to have been made by a winemaker of colour. But things are changing. There‚Äôs an increasing determination to improve opportunities, notably for young South Africans who want to enter the industry. Initiatives such as the Cape Winemakers Guild (CWG) Proteg√© programme, which enables newly graduated winemakers from disadvantaged backgrounds to spend time working with some of the country‚Äôs leading winemakers, have benefited several award-winning youngsters. They incl‚Ä¶

entry.title: Myanmar: UN seeks additional $240 million to bolster earthquake relief
entry.summary: The United Nations is ramping up its response to Myanmar‚Äôs devastating earthquake, calling for increased funding and an immediate ceasefire to ensure more aid reaches those in desperate need.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Bombardment, deprivation and displacement continue in Gaza
entry.summary: Hostilities across the Gaza Strip continue to take a devastating toll on the population, with daily reports of Israeli strikes killing and injuring many civilians, UN aid coordination office OCHA said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan faces unprecedented hunger and displacement as war enters third year
entry.summary: The conflict in Sudan has become one of the worst humanitarian crises of the 21st century, leaving millions of women, children and displaced families suffering from violence, food insecurity and the collapse of essential services.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO warns of severe disruptions to health services amid funding cuts
entry.summary: Recent funding cuts have caused ‚Äúsevere disruptions‚Äù to health services in almost three-quarters of all countries, according to the head of the UN World Health Organization (WHO),¬†Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Spare developing countries from new US tariffs: UN trade chief
entry.summary: As governments and global markets struggle to deal with the deep concerns and disruptions caused by trade tariffs, Rebeca Grynspan, the head of the UN trade and development agency (UNCTAD), told UN News on Thursday that the poorest countries ‚Äì whose activities have a negligible effect on trade deficits ‚Äì should be exempt.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria‚Äôs political transition at risk due to Israeli military action, Security Council hears
entry.summary: Recent military actions by Israel are undermining Syria‚Äôs political transition and the chances of a new security pact between the two countries, a senior UN official told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Court begins hearing Sudan‚Äôs ‚Äòcomplicity in genocide‚Äô case against the United Arab Emirates
entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) on Thursday began hearing Sudan‚Äôs case against the United Arab Emirates (UAE), which it accuses of being complicit in acts of genocide against the Masalit community in West Darfur by backing the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF).

entry.title: Preventable ‚Äòmeningitis belt‚Äô deaths targeted in health agency action plan

entry.title: Why Scotland‚Äôs Argyll & the Isles should be your next getaway
entry.summary:
West of Glasgow, the peninsula of Argyll stretches towards its cluster of neighbouring isles, which fan out in all their marvellous diversity. Although small on the map, this part of Scotland has more than 2,300 miles of coast ‚Äî about as much as South Africa ‚Äî and 23 inhabited islands, each with their own character. After exploring the mainland‚Äôs castles and lochs, head to the fishing port of Oban to fill up on lobsters and mussels. From there, you can depart for an island adventure where you might set forth in a sea kayak, get a taste of the region‚Äôs 24 whisky and gin distilleries, or scale a mighty Munro ‚Äî a mountain that towers above 3,000 ft. From sipping scotch fireside, to navigating wild Atlantic coastlines, here‚Äôs how to explore Scotland's rugged western shores.
Argyll & the‚Ä¶

entry.title: Love reading? These are the best book towns around the world
entry.summary:
Wigtown, known as "Scotland's Book Town," has a 10-day literary festival every fall. In these small towns from Scotland to New Zealand, books shape identity, tourism, and community. 
In the Welsh village of Hay-on-Wye, where sheep outnumber people and books spill onto the streets, a quiet revolution began. Antiquarian and academic Richard Booth inadvertently launched a global movement when he began filling the empty buildings of Hay-on-Wye with secondhand books.
What started as a single decision in 1961 to fill his sleepy hometown with secondhand books to sell in numerous empty buildings, turned into the birthplace of a global literary mecca uniting villages, bibliophiles, and dreamers alike.¬†
People from across the United Kingdom swarmed this small town, and soon bo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why is everyone looking up in Tucson?
entry.summary:
Nine people are crammed in a tiny room with no ceiling on the grounds of¬†Kitt Peak National Observatory. It‚Äôs cold. It‚Äôs dark. Each person awaits a turn at the eyepiece of a 20-inch telescope trained on an object. A marbled sphere, swirled in colors of maroon, rust, and cream. It‚Äôs Jupiter, a fellow planet in our solar system, fifth from the sun. ‚ÄúLook at that black speck that kinda looks like dirt on the lens,‚Äù says guide James Schweder. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs Io, one of Jupiter‚Äôs moons, casting its shadow on the planet.‚Äù He puts the show in perspective. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre basically watching a solar eclipse from more than 417 million miles away.‚Äù¬†
With a surfeit of blockbuster attractions as the Grand Canyon, Sedona, Monument Valley and the Hoover Dam in the state, travelers to Arizona can be forgiven for o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Saudi Arabia's vast desert was once a lush, green paradise
entry.summary:
A new study of stalagmites in caves in central Saudi Arabia¬†provides strong evidence that the region was lush and green for much of the last eight million years‚Äîa phenomenon known as ‚ÄúGreen Arabia,‚Äù but until now only a hypothesis.
The study also indicates that the central band of the world‚Äôs ‚Äúbarrier‚Äù deserts‚Äî¬†from the Sahara in the west, across Arabia and to India‚Äôs Thar Desert in the east‚Äîwere at times well-watered, savannah-like landscapes that encouraged the migrations of primates and other animals out of Africa, including Homo sapiens and some of our hominin ancestors.
‚ÄúThe sand seas that we are used to seeing have not always been the case,‚Äù says archaeologist Michael Petraglia, the director of the Australian Research Centre for Human Evolution at Griffith University. ‚ÄúThat‚Ä¶

entry.title: Exploring Nova Scotia? These are the towns to visit
entry.summary:
UNESCO-listed Lunenburg remains one of the best-preserved colonial settlements in North America, with around 70% of its original architecture still standing. Nova Scotia‚Äôs cultural landscape is as diverse as its coastline, shaped by Mi'kmaq, French Acadian and African Nova Scotian communities. A coastal road trip, winding along wave-worn cliffs and tranquil, island-studded bays, invites travellers to uncover the rich heritage that runs deep along its shores.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At dawn, mist seeps across the wave-carved headland of Peggy‚Äôs Cove, softening the edges of the shoreline and cloaking the whitewashed lighthouse in an ethereal veil. Below, the Atlantic pounds against the granite rocks, sending salt spray into the morning ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How these death-defying beetles can help human health
entry.summary:
American burying beetle (Nicrophorus americanus) Scientists are studying the American burying beetle's death-defying resilience to benefit human health.
Among the latest contenders in the fight against drug-resistant infections is a striking, black beetle with fiery red spots and orange-tipped antennae. Known for spending much of its life underground, the little-known American burying beetle could hold the key to developing the next generation of antibiotic treatments.¬†
For the past two decades, researchers have investigated how the beetle preserves meat at room temperature, seeking to harness its antibacterial, antifungal, and food preservation properties for human use. Now, scientists have discovered a new super power: These beetles are even resistant to powerful deadly inse‚Ä¶

entry.title: This strange phenomenon turns the ocean milky white‚Äîbut how?
entry.summary:
‚ÄúIt looked as if we were sailing over a boundless plain of snow, or a sea of quicksilver,‚Äù writes Captain Kempthorne in his ship‚Äôs log.
Sailing a ship called Moozuffer through the Arabian Sea in January 1849, he witnessed something so rare that there are under 400 known records in 400 years and just one photo.
This ghostly phenomenon, called milky seas, has puzzled sailors and scientists for centuries.
After delving into centuries of ship logs like Kempthorne's, eyewitness accounts, newspapers, and satellite imagery, Justin Hudson, PhD candidate at Colorado State University (CSU) and Steven Miller, an atmospheric scientist also at CSU, have published the world's largest database of milky sea observations¬†in the journal Earth and Space Science.
In it, they write that ‚Äúth‚Ä¶

Cloudflare Snippets are now generally available (GA) for all paid plansÔºå giving you a fastÔºå flexible way to control HTTP traffic using lightweight JavaScript 'code rules' --- at no extra cost. Snippets bring the power of JavaScript to Cloudflare RulesÔºå letting you write logic that runs before a request reaches your origin or after a response returns from upstream. Snippets are fastÔºå flexibleÔºå and freeÔºå but how do they compare to Cloudflare Workers? Both allow you to programmatically control traffic. entry.title: GIJN Webinar: Gathering Evidence and Documents in Conflict and War Zones ‚Äî A MENA Case Study
entry.summary: In this GIJN webinar, we‚Äôll explore how investigative journalists can document human rights abuses in war zones, with a focus on methods to ensure the information gathered can later be used by legal investigators or international courts. Drawing from their on-the-ground experience in Syria, Iraq, and Palestine, our expert panel will share practical tools, ethical considerations, and field-tested techniques for recording testimony, analyzing open source material, and archiving evidence in a secure and legally sound manner.

entry.title: World News in Brief: East Jerusalem schools told to close, Guterres saddened by Santo Domingo deaths, DR Congo and Haiti updates
entry.summary: Six schools run by the UN Palestine refugee agency (UNRWA) in East Jerusalem have been issued ‚Äúillegal closure orders‚Äù after being forcibly entered by Israeli security forces, according to the agency‚Äôs head Philippe Lazzarini.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: March proves deadly month for civilians in Ukraine
entry.summary: More than three years on from the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, Ukrainian civilians continue to face the devastating consequences of war, with March 2025 proving to be another deadly month.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: South Sudan: Conflict and hunger push millions to the brink
entry.summary: Hunger in South Sudan‚Äôs northeast has reached a critical tipping point, with nearly 7.7 million people facing severe food insecurity as conflict escalates, the UN‚Äôs emergency food relief agency warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Fear and uncertainty are daily staples for Gaza‚Äôs most vulnerable
entry.summary: In Gaza, ongoing Israeli military operations and the aid blockade have continued to add to daily fears and hardships being faced by those about to give birth in the devastated enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: UNHCR chief stresses need to help refugee hosts in Chad
entry.summary: As the brutal war in Sudan nears the two-year mark, thousands of people continue to flee into neighbouring countries, including Chad, UN refugee agency chief Filippo Grandi said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Northern Thai communities put nature before profit
entry.summary: The people of Mae Hong Son and Tak provinces in northwestern Thailand have lived in balance with nature for hundreds of years and many of them depend on rivers and forests for their livelihoods.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: This chef is proving Eastern European food is more than cabbage
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
How would you define the cuisine of Eastern Europe?
The tradition of sharing food around the table with multiple generations and passing on stories through recipes is at the heart of Eastern European cuisine. There‚Äôs also a sense of diversity across cultural and ethnic groups.
In terms of specific dishes, techniques and ingredients, fermentation spans the region. Pies are a simple way of making the most of a few ingredients. And there will always be some form of dumpling. Sour cream is used for stirring into sauces or soups and for dipping dumplings, fritters or pancakes. In summer, there‚Äôs an abundance of herbs ‚Äî dill, parsley, coriander ‚Äî and lots of simple but fragrant spices like caraway, fennel seeds and ‚Ä¶

entry.title: San Diego: A culture capital
entry.summary:
When travelers speak of sunny San Diego, they talk about more than the weather. Sure, California‚Äôs second-largest city boasts an average of 266 sunny days each year. But San Diego Symphony Music Director Rafael Payare says San Diego residents' infectious optimism and warm disposition also welcome visitors to join in on the good vibes. ‚ÄúI am already going into my sixth year with the Orchestra, and being surrounded by the beautiful landscape of San Diego has touched me deeply.‚Äù
With a population of 1.4 million people, San Diego is a bona fide big city with eclectic museums, historic art centers, and world-class performing arts. And yet, its charming neighborhoods and laid-back attitude foster a down-to-earth community vibe. undefined undefined Visitors to the city regularly‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 of the dreamiest stargazing trains in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Each Verde Canyon Starlight train service has a local astronomer on board to help point out constellations and other useful information. From the Nevada desert to the Oregon coast, these heritage railroads allow you to see the stars while rolling through the countryside.
Light pollution is worsening by 10 percent every year, and as our starry skies vanish, so does our connection to the cosmos. But there‚Äôs still an unlikely place for a dark-sky escape: Aboard one of America‚Äôs historical railways.
A variety of stargazing trains roll through rural landscapes and protected dark-sky preserves where the Milky Way still shines bright, sometimes with a telescope or astronomer on board or an open-air carriage for looking up at the night sky. A train ride offers the perfect chance to sl‚Ä¶

entry.title: This simple doodad is saving our feet on long flights
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
You cross and uncross your legs. You push your personal item to the side. You attempt to use said personal item as an ottoman, but nothing makes the space around your feet comfortable. Except, perhaps, a foot hammock.¬†
They may look funky, but these simple slings attach to the tray table on a plane or train to create a suspended foot rest that may help improve circulation and ease lower back pain, according to Amish Dudeja, a Georgia-based foot and‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to explore Romania's wild Danube Delta by boat
entry.summary:
The marshes along Romania‚Äôs Danube Delta is particularly popular for hobby fishing. Romania‚Äôs section of the Danube Delta brims with natural wonders, but Letea Forest, a stretch of the wetland where green woods grow on shifting sand dunes and horses run wild, is especially captivating.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
I‚Äôm gliding down a narrow waterway on a small, open-deck viewing boat deep in the marshes. Next to me, wild horses graze on green plains, while on the horizon, ancient woods shimmer in the morning sun. ‚ÄúNobody knows how this forest came to be,‚Äù says local guide and wildlife expert Daniel Petrescu, binoculars in hand.
Having joined a four-day, small-group cruise exploring one of Europe‚Äôs largest wetlands, I‚Äôm in Romania‚Äôs se‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who should really be allowed to dig for dinosaurs?
entry.summary:
In the 1980s, amateur paleontologists dug up this fossilized jaw of an abelisaurid in Provence, France. The French countryside is rich in fossilized eggs, footprints, and bones. A battle is raging over who is allowed to hunt for them.
One scorching day¬†last September, Annie M√©chin crouched over a slab of red clay on a remote patch of farmland near Marseille, on France‚Äôs Mediterranean coast. M√©chin was scraping away at the clay when she unearthed what looked like a tiny bone fragment. Sensing the familiar jolt of adrenaline that surged anytime she came across a fossil, she called out to her husband, Patrick, who was digging nearby. Carefully, the two amateur paleontologists, both retired and in their 60s, cleared the surface area, dug a small trench around the bone, and fashioned a ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Cicadas are back‚Äîand this time it‚Äôs the ‚Äòmother of all broods‚Äô
entry.summary:
The last time the periodical¬†cicadas¬†known as Brood XIV emerged, Netflix was still sending DVDs through the mail, people were buying ringtones for their Blackberries, and Barack Obama was about to be elected president of the United States. ¬†
Seventeen years later, the world is a very different place. But for periodical cicadas, which spend more than a decade underground as nymphs before emerging in one giant wave as winged adults, it‚Äôs business as usual.
‚ÄúBrood XIV is the same brood that was first recorded in 1634 by the pilgrims in the Plymouth colony,‚Äù says¬†Gene Kritsky, professor emeritus at Mount St. Joseph College in Ohio, who‚Äôs been studying cicadas for more than 50 years. ‚ÄúAnd there it is, still emerging in Plymouth.‚Äù
Of course, it would be another century before ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Traveling solo? Here are 7 ideal destinations
entry.summary:
A solo getaway offers the ideal opportunity to immerse oneself in the authentic culture, history, and expression of a particular destination. There are no limits to where inspiration may take you, nor should there be. Whether it‚Äôs a Michelin-starred meal or an adrenaline-inducing adventure, with some planning and expert advice, your next solo journey can reach new heights.¬†¬†
There may be no better combination than a pint and a good book‚Äîand no better destination to imbibe in said lager and literature than Oscar Wilde‚Äôs birthplace,¬†Dublin, Ireland. Art and cultural historian¬†Dr. Andrew Lear, a scholar of Wilde‚Äôs work, suggests a hotel with historical significance. ‚ÄúI highly recommend¬†The Shelbourne, where Oscar Wilde stayed when on a speaking tour in Dublin,‚Äù says Lear.
Leave ro‚Ä¶

entry.title: This animal sanctuary lets you track rare rhinos on foot in Kenya
entry.summary:
Sand sifts through the fingers of Jimmy Lekiondo, a Samburu safari guide at¬†Saruni Rhino¬†who specializes in rhino tracking. It blows to the ground as he scans the trees with squinted eyes. Noticing my curiosity, he whispers,¬†‚ÄúRhinos can‚Äôt see well but are very sensitive to smell. We do this to ensure they don‚Äôt catch our scent.‚Äù¬†Motioning for me to follow, he cautions,¬†‚ÄúWalk lightly.‚Äù¬†Rhinos are also highly sensitive to sound.
‚ÄúThere!‚Äù¬†Lekiondo stops and suddenly points. Between the bushes, I see what looks like a giant grey boulder. Then, it moves. A massive southern white rhino stands. Startled by its size, I leap behind Lekiondo, spooking the rhino, which bolts in the opposite direction.¬†‚ÄúNever move until I say,‚Äù¬†he warns, clearly frustrated. In this environment, following instruct‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why this little-visited South American capital is worth a look
entry.summary:
Plaza Independencia hosts the Artigas Statue near the Ciudad Vieja. The Uruguayan capital flies under the radar, but has an atmospheric old town, a rich musical and literary heritage and beachside barrios to discover.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At first glance, Montevideo has much in common with Buenos Aires, lying on the opposite side of the River Plate. Football, tango and world-class steaks are all found here, though you‚Äôre more likely to see Montevideanos strolling around with a mate ‚Äî a herbal tea made from the yerba mate plant ‚Äî than a coffee. But spend some time in the Uruguayan capital, and you‚Äôll soon discover that its draws go far beyond any similarities.
The Ciudad Vieja (Old City) is its oldest and most atmospheric neigh‚Ä¶

Mosquito repellents are a great defense for these small but formidable creatures. In addition to causing itching, mosquito bites can transmit diseases like malaria, West Nile, dengue, and chikungunya, according to Richard J. Pollack, Ph.D., senior environmental public health officer at Harvard University.¬†
Pollack explains that choosing the right mosquito repellent depends on the person and the circumstances. However, ‚Äúa good repellent can dramatica‚Ä¶

entry.title: The shingles vaccine may reduce your dementia risk‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
Shingles, a viral rash, can be incredibly painful. Vaccination can help prevent the infection, but new research is showing the vaccine may also have another benefit: protecting against the development of dementia.
In April, a¬†study published in Nature observed the risk of dementia in adults who received the shingles vaccine versus those who had not. Researchers found that those who were vaccinated against shingles had a 20 percent lower chance of developing dementia. This new evidence is part of a growing body of research linking vaccinations against infections like shingles, the flu, and pneumonia with a reduced risk of dementia, says Paul Schulz, a professor of neurology at UTHealth Houston who was not involved in the study.¬†
Approximately one million Americans are diagnosed ‚Ä¶

Before any good beach trip, most of us run through a familiar mental checklist: Hat? Check. Sunscreen? Check. Oversized beach bag? Check. But we may not put much thought into beach towels.¬†
These days, ‚Äúnot all beach towels are created equal,‚Äù says Jayme Keffalas, a fashion and travel blogger with The Northern Prepster. That‚Äôs because beach towels are now made from a variety of high-quality fabrics with features like sand repelling, quick drying, a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Visiting the Titanic is suddenly a lot easier than you think
entry.summary:
This rendering of the Titanic is based on 715,000 photos and millions of laser scans of the famous wreck, which were stitched together to create a perfect digital replica of what remains of the ship. Fresh advances in 3D scanning technology are making it possible to explore some of the hardest-to-reach and most fragile sites on Earth.
Last year, Parks Stephenson¬†stood next to the¬†Titanic¬†and walked slowly around it, gazing up at the massive ship. He paused to look inside one of the boiler rooms and at the position of the controls on the engines. He noticed the number 401, the ship‚Äôs ID, etched on the propeller blades. Rusticles hung from the steel shell. Twisted metal and personal trinkets from those long dead littered the ground.
Stephenson, a retired naval officer and¬†Titani‚Ä¶

entry.title: 5 ways to explore Tanzania's islands
entry.summary:
With almost 900 miles of tropical Indian Ocean shoreline, Tanzania is as much a coastal destination as it is a safari hotspot. The warm islands sitting off the coast of this East African nation are steeped in heritage, lined with sandy beaches and fringed by coral reefs. Often known as the Swahili Coast, the region is a fascinating swirl of Bantu traditions and Islamic influences. The marine life here ‚Äî which includes whale sharks, a legally protected species in Tanzania ‚Äî is a huge draw for travellers and a natural wonder that locals are working hard to protect. From relaxing on Pemba Island's untouched beaches to wandering the historic streets of Zanzibar, here are five experiences to savour across Tanzania‚Äôs eastern islands.
For first timers to Tanzania, Jumeirah Thanda Island pr‚Ä¶

The best reef-safe sunscreens will help protect you from the sun, while keeping reefs safe from chemicals. When news broke back in 2015 that oxybenzone, a common chemical in sunscreens, was incredibly toxic to young coral and other marine life, we all began to look twice at our SPF protection. Since then, more common chemicals in sunscreen formulas have been added to the list of harmful ingredients, and tropical destinations like Hawaii, Aruba, and Key W‚Ä¶

entry.title: Sea moss is a billion-dollar health trend. Is it worth the hype?
entry.summary:
Sea moss‚Äîalso known as Irish moss or Chondrus crispus‚Äîis having a social media moment. Celebrities and Tiktokers promote it for everything from better digestion to glowing skin. But is the hype backed by science?
Sold as dried flakes, gels, powders, gummies, and pills, sea moss has become a billion-dollar industry, valued at $2.18 billion in 2024, and the global market is expected to grow to $2.60 billion by 2030, according to Virtue Market Research.¬†
But while sea moss is being promoted as a ‚Äúsuperfood,‚Äù much of what ends up in your supplement bottle barely resembles the raw algae. Carrageenan, an ultra-processed form of sea moss used to emulsify or thicken foods and drinks in the food industry, is stripped of most of the nutrients, including soluble fiber, and may disrupt the g‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 166 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from March 24 to March 30, 2025. A total of 3,605 panelists responded out of 4,045 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans Give Early Trump Foreign Policy Actions Mixed or Negative Reviews
entry.summary: More disapprove than approve of leaving the WHO and ending USAID. About half see tariffs on China as bad for the U.S. and them personally, but views differ by party. The post Americans Give Early Trump Foreign Policy Actions Mixed or Negative Reviews appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Kosovo‚Äôs inclusive and peaceful election marks progress, but challenges remain
entry.summary: Kosovo‚Äôs recent parliamentary election ‚Äì conducted peacefully and inclusively ‚Äì marked a significant step in its democratic development, the UN‚Äôs top envoy said on Tuesday, noting gains in women‚Äôs representation.

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: 41,700 refugees have fled violence to Uganda
entry.summary: Some 41,000 refugees have crossed from the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) into Uganda since January, many of them having witnessed killings, ‚Äúsexual violence and other traumatic experience during their flight,‚Äù said the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine crisis: ‚ÄòEven wars have rules,‚Äô UN relief chief tells Security Council
entry.summary: Nearly 13 million people in Ukraine urgently need humanitarian aid as displacement, psychological trauma and the destruction of essential services continues to take a devastating toll, the UN relief chief warned on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Guterres calls on Israel to ensure life-saving aid reaches civilians
entry.summary: With no aid allowed into Gaza for more than a month, the UN Secretary-General appealed on Tuesday for guaranteed humanitarian access to the enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Dangers grow for Myanmar quake survivors, health system 'overwhelmed'
entry.summary: In earthquake-shattered central Myanmar, people are sleeping in the streets in fear of buildings collapsing, facing early monsoon rains and the risk of waterborne diseases, the UN warned on Tuesday.

üí¨ ÊñáÁ´†ÈáëÂè•
AutoRAG continuously monitors your data sources and indexes in the background so your AI stays fresh without manual effort. RAG solves this by retrieving relevant information from your data source at query timeÔºå combining it with the user's input queryÔºå and feeding both into the LLM to generate responses grounded with your data. AutoRAG is built entirely on top of Cloudflare's Developer PlatformÔºå using the same tools you'd reach for if you were building a RAG pipeline yourself. üìä ÊñáÁ´†‰ø°ÊÅØ

Workflows is a durable execution engine built on Cloudflare Workers that allows you to build resilientÔºå multi-step applications. (Workflows ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊûÑÂª∫Âú® Cloudflare Workers ‰∏äÁöÑÊåÅ‰πÖÂåñÊâßË°åÂºïÊìéÔºåÂÆÉÂÖÅËÆ∏‰Ω†ÊûÑÂª∫ÂÖ∑ÊúâÂºπÊÄßÁöÑÂ§öÊ≠•È™§Â∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇ) This durable execution model is particularly powerful for applications that coordinate between multiple systemsÔºå process data in sequenceÔºå or need to handle long-running tasks that might span minutesÔºå hoursÔºå or even days. (ËøôÁßçÊåÅ‰πÖÂåñÊâßË°åÊ®°ÂûãÂØπ‰∫éÈúÄË¶ÅÂú®Â§ö‰∏™Á≥ªÁªü‰πãÈó¥ÂçèË∞É„ÄÅÊåâÈ°∫Â∫èÂ§ÑÁêÜÊï∞ÊçÆÊàñÈúÄË¶ÅÂ§ÑÁêÜÂèØËÉΩË∑®Ë∂äÊï∞ÂàÜÈíü„ÄÅÊï∞Â∞èÊó∂ÁîöËá≥Êï∞Â§©ÁöÑÈïøÊó∂Èó¥ËøêË°å‰ªªÂä°ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÊù•ËØ¥Â∞§ÂÖ∂Âº∫Â§ß„ÄÇ) With WorkflowsÔºå just like Workers: you don't pay for time your application is just waiting. entry.title: Reporter, ProPublica-Texas Tribune Initiative
entry.summary: ProPublica is hiring a reporter to join its joint investigative unit with The Texas Tribune. We‚Äôre looking for a dogged, accountability-focused reporter who is passionate about exposing harm and has a track record of producing revelatory journalism that is both short-term and long-term. The position is part of a collaboration formed between the two organizations [‚Ä¶]

entry.title: Reporter, National
entry.summary: We are hiring a reporter to join us on the national staff of one of America‚Äôs most innovative, collaborative and ambitious investigative newsrooms. We‚Äôre looking for a reporter with a record of producing powerful accountability stories that surprise, uncover injustice, deliver life-altering revelations and bring about change. See vacancy

entry.title: Graphics Editor
entry.summary: ProPublica is seeking a graphics editor to create information graphics for stories with real-world impact. You will work closely with ProPublica‚Äôs award-winning journalists to pitch, conceptualize, design and build charts like our explainer on the new effects of immigration or car loan interest rates, maps like our analysis of Wisconsin legislative districts or Colorado wildfires, [‚Ä¶]

entry.title: Assistant Professor of Practice in Open-Source Investigative Journalism
entry.summary: The University of Memphis, a vibrant urban public research institution, seeks a dedicated and innovative Assistant Professor of Practice in Open-Source Investigative Journalism in the Department of Journalism and Strategic Media. We invite applications from journalists with significant experience and expertise in open-source investigative methods, data journalism, visual investigations, or investigative journalism. See vacancy

entry.title: Investigative Journalism in MENA: Struggling Against Tyranny, Fighting to Survive
entry.summary: As part of GIJN's MENA Focus Week, we talked to investigative journalists across the region about their biggest challenges ‚Äî from repressive laws and surveillance to funding cuts.

entry.title: Aid cuts threaten to roll back progress in ending maternal mortality
entry.summary: Unprecedented aid cuts are putting global progress to end maternal deaths at risk, three UN agencies warned in a new report that calls for greater investment in midwives and other health workers.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief urges probe into Russian attack that killed nine children in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights called on Sunday for an investigation into the Russian attack on the Ukrainian city of Kryvyi Rih which reportedly killed 18 people, including nine children.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: Monday‚Äôs¬†World Health Day highlights a critical issue for global health: the particular vulnerabilities faced by women and girls.

entry.title: Why you should visit Greece's 'city of gastronomy'
entry.summary:
Thessaloniki's Ano Poli neighbourhood comes alive for lunch time thanks to traditional ouzerias like Tsinari. For two millennia, UNESCO City of Gastronomy Thessaloniki has been celebrated for its food culture, with flavours imported from across Europe, Africa and the Middle East.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The sun has just popped over Thessaloniki‚Äôs jumbled rooftops but there‚Äôs already a queue out the door at Bougatsa Bantis. Inside, baker Philippos Bantis is handling the morning rush, bantering with his customers, many of whom he greets by name. It doesn‚Äôt take long to get through the orders, since they‚Äôre all for the same thing: bougatsa, the rich, crispy, buttery filo tart that‚Äôs a breakfast staple in Thessaloniki. Traditionally, it‚Äôs‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Thai prison is the best place to get a massage
Heard about The Ghan? Try Australia's other outback train instead
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Three hours: that‚Äôs how long it takes Shelita Buffet to get ready. There are false eyelashes to glue and cheekbones to contour; there‚Äôs a neon-bright wig to preen and a sequined pink leotard to tug on ‚Äî and then there‚Äôs the generous application of glitter to beard. Looking this good takes time. The first honeyed rays of dawn have only just begun to wash into the mining town of Broken Hill and Shelita is standing on the station platform in a pair of blocky white heels, watching as I step off the train.
I‚Äôd boarded in Sydney the day before, leaving behind the skyscrapers and the Opera House‚Äôs monumental clutch of alabaster shells to make tracks on a journey of continental proportions, rattling east to west across the‚Ä¶

entry.title: These birds are keeping a record of humanity‚Äîone wrapper at a time
entry.summary:
Coots, rotund black waterbirds with big feet, don‚Äôt seem like they‚Äôd run the waterways. But in Amsterdam, they‚Äôre the ‚Äúcanal gangsters,‚Äù territorial and tenacious. They moved in from nearby farms more than thirty years ago, and they‚Äôve toughed it out even in the dense urban core.
Scientists are researching how coots and other birds adapt to urban environments and whether that move is even a good thing.
Now, a new study unravels thirty years of plastic trash in one of the city‚Äôs biggest coot nests, revealing when coots build and breed in the city.
One particularly large nest documented 30 years of coots living in the red-light district. The oldest item in the nest was a Mars bar advertising the 1994 World Cup; the newest, a protein bar wrapper. Candy packaging, McDonald‚Äôs san‚Ä¶

entry.title: How the Portuguese influenced Thailand‚Äôs cuisine
entry.summary:
Bangkok‚Äôs Kudi Chin neighborhood, in Thonburi on the western bank of the Chao Praya river, is a sleepy one; a jumble of narrow alleys and old houses, some on stilts. It is sometimes called Little Portugal, as it is home to a number of Thais descended from the Portuguese, who had settled here in the late 18th century.
The Portuguese were the first Western nation to contact the ancient Thai kingdom of Ayutthaya in 1511. They soon became a prominent trading partner, and introduced a number of fruits and vegetables, which are now staples in Thai cuisine. As Edward Van Roy writes in Siamese Melting Pot, tomatoes, chillies, peanuts, potatoes, and maize came to Thailand via Portugal. Some of the Thai names for vegetables reflect their imported origin; for example, potatoes are called man f‚Ä¶

entry.title: The rise and fall (and rise again?) of measles in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Measles cases continue to grow in the United States, which experts link to a rise in personal exemptions for school vaccine mandates. Measles requires 95 percent of a community to be immune to prevent the disease from spreading but the rise of exemptions in some communities has increased their risk of outbreaks.  The U.S. eliminated measles in 2000‚Äîbut that hard-won achievement is now under threat. To contain the current outbreak, some states are following a new playbook to fight the infectious disease.
As the measles outbreak that began in West Texas continues to escalate‚Äîwith the number of U.S. cases this year now surpassing all those recorded in 2024‚Äîso does misinformation about how the disease spreads and how to prevent it.

entry.title: How Hello Kitty helped post-WWII Japan conquer the world
entry.summary:
To much of the world, Hello Kitty is a charming cartoon icon‚Äîa blank-faced cat with a red bow and an empire of lunch boxes, backpacks, and billion-dollar branding. But her global rise tells a far more complex story.
Born in 1974 amid Japan‚Äôs efforts to recover from the devastation of World War II, Hello Kitty would become an unlikely agent of national reinvention. As the country confronted its imperialist past and sought to repair its international image, a quiet cultural revolution emerged‚Äîrooted in the aesthetics of cuteness, or kawaii.
Through Hello Kitty, Japan began to reintroduce itself to the world‚Äînot as a former military power but as a rising expert in soft power.
At the end of World War II, Japan faced a reckoning. The country‚Äôs surrender in 1945 forced its polit‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why hikers should ditch the Alps for this mountain range
entry.summary:
Hikers should consider visiting the Carpathian Alps, which includes Romania‚Äôs Transylvanian Alps, instead of the Swiss Alps. It‚Äôs not only a cost-effective option, but this mountain range has abundant wildlife, cultural sites, quaint villages, and the new Via Transilvanica hiking trail. The Transylvanian Alps provide visitors with abundant wildlife, UNESCO World Heritage sites, and quaint villages‚Äîwithout the crowds.
Why hikers should try this mountain range in RomaniaHikers pause on a ridgeline trail to look for the perfect selfie shot. Will their backdrop for the Instagram-worthy photo be the snow-dusted peaks or alpine meadows dotted with wild daisies and bellflowers? Meanwhile, below, traditional wooden churches poke through the morning mist; their spires rising above rustic vi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Pakistan's mountains are calling‚Äîhere's why you should go
entry.summary:
The Karakoram range in Baltistan ‚Äî even at 20,000ft, Laila Peak does not fall into the range‚Äôs 100 tallest summits. Pakistan‚Äôs far north holds some of the world‚Äôs highest peaks and has a proud cultural identity, but until now international visitors have been thin on the ground. A new hiking tour explores a spectacular corner of an often misunderstood country.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).

In the throng, details catch the eye: henna-dyed beards and candy-striped hijabs; a knife-sharpener showering sparks over the pavement; four passengers and a goat in an auto-rickshaw. entry.title: Centuries of history reduced to rubble after Myanmar earthquake
entry.summary: This building lies in rubble after a 7.7 magnitude earthquake struck Myanmar on March 28, 2025. Myanmar's Information Minister Maung Maung Ohn announced at a meeting in the capital that 4,589 people were injured and 221 others are missing as of  April 4, 2025. Myanmar's religious temples stood as symbols of faith and history. After the recent 7.7 magnitude earthquake, many are wondering: will they ever rise again or are they lost forever? entry.title: The poison fruit from ‚ÄòThe White Lotus‚Äô is real
entry.summary:
Forbidden fruit has been a theme across all seasons of The White Lotus, HBO‚Äôs series about a fictional high-end hotel chain. In season three, set in Thailand, the metaphor becomes literal when a hotel worker warns a guest not to eat the fruit of the pong pong tree, as it is toxic enough to kill.¬†
Fans of the show are now chattering about whether that deadly narrative seed, planted in the season premiere, will bear fruit in the 90-minute finale as the character Timothy Ratliff‚Äôs suicidal ideations continue to escalate.
(Inspired by White Lotus? Here are the Thai islands to visit.)
But what fans might not know is that the pong pong tree (Cerbera odollam) is a real poisonous plant that has been implicated in thousands of deaths a year in the past. The effects of its deadly frui‚Ä¶

entry.title: Are tornadoes getting worse? Here's what we know
entry.summary:
Natural disasters like heat waves, fires, and floods are growing more dangerous because of climate change, but the effect a warming world has on tornadoes is complicated and inconclusive.
There‚Äôs been a recorded increase in the overall number of observed tornadoes since 1950, according to National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration data, but experts say that‚Äôs largely a result of better technology such as Doppler radar. There‚Äôs been no observed increase in the frequency of major tornadoes over time. ¬†
But given the pervasive influence of global warming on the atmosphere, it's unavoidable that climate change would impact tornadoes too, said Victor Gensini, an extreme weather expert at Northern Illinois University.
‚ÄúInstead of asking: ‚ÄòDid climate change cause this tornado‚Ä¶

entry.title: Are we alone in the universe? These Mars rocks may tell us
entry.summary:
Across the Martian landscape, the view is breathtaking. Everything is quiet, except for a little robot patiently trundling up the sides of Jezero Crater. Perseverance, affectionately known as ‚ÄúPercy,‚Äù doesn‚Äôt have the ability to appreciate the reddish-orange hues of the desert landscape like a human can. But the rover has been exploring the red planet since 2021, and it‚Äôs been carefully amassing a rock collection that could change our understanding of Mars‚Äô history, how it compares to our own planet, and how we came to be here.
Mars wasn‚Äôt always a desolate, dusty world. Scientists think that, at some point in the red planet‚Äôs history, it was temperate much like Earth is today. But around three or four billion years ago, Mars‚Äôs internal plumbing mysteriously shut off‚Äîand as a result, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza: Paramedic still missing after aid worker killings, Palestinian Red Crescent Society calls for answers
entry.summary: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) on Friday called for urgent answers over the whereabouts of a missing paramedic, coupled with a full independent investigation into the killing of 15 humanitarian workers in Gaza on 23 March.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Cholera surges worldwide, DR Congo update, WHO leads global health emergency exercise
entry.summary: A global surge in cholera is threatening vulnerable people from Angola to Myanmar, fuelled by conflict, natural disasters and climate change, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rolls out key initiative to combat antisemitism
entry.summary: Amid rising concerns over antisemitism worldwide, the UN on Friday announced the roll out of a major action plan to combat the scourge ‚Äì aimed at enhancing monitoring and response across the whole UN system.

entry.title: UN rights office calls for end to Israel's ‚Äòillegal presence‚Äô in the Occupied Palestinian Territory
entry.summary: Amid reports of escalating settler violence in the West Bank, the UN rights office, OHCHR, briefed the Palestinian rights committee at UN Headquarters in New York, which also featured a screening of the Oscar winning documentary No Other Land.

entry.title: ‚ÄòSafe futures start here‚Äô: UN calls for global action to eliminate mine threat
entry.summary: More than 100 million people worldwide are at risk from landmines, explosive remnants of war and improvised explosive devices (IEDs) Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres said on Friday, in his message for the¬†International Day for Mine Awareness.

entry.title: Sudan: Suffering continues amid massive destruction across Khartoum
entry.summary: The people of Sudan are trapped in siege-like conditions ‚Äúwith no escape, no hope, and often forced to face unspeakable abuse,‚Äù a senior official with the UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) said on Friday in Geneva.

entry.title: Myanmar quake: Airstrikes continue despite ceasefire
entry.summary: Myanmar‚Äôs military has continued to launch airstrikes and other attacks against opposition forces in the devastated country, one week since a 7.7 magnitude earthquake struck and despite agreeing to a ceasefire, UN human rights chief Volker T√ºrk said on Friday.

entry.summary: Acting is an ancient and intrinsically human way to establish vibrant connections with one another. And it‚Äôs available to us all - by John Britton Read at Aeon

entry.title: Appendix A: Demographic makeup of AI experts surveyed
entry.summary: The post Appendix A: Demographic makeup of AI experts surveyed appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Selected tables by expert and public demographics
entry.summary: Note: We did not receive enough responses from Hispanic or Black experts to be able to report expert views by race and ethnicity; this reflects the racial and ethnic makeup of the field. These groups‚Äô responses are incorporated into the general figures throughout. We also did not receive enough responses from experts working at nonprofits, [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix B: Selected tables by expert and public demographics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This report is based on a pair of Pew Research Center surveys and a series of in-depth interviews. It draws on a nationally representative survey of U.S. adults who are members of the Center‚Äôs American Trends Panel (ATP), a survey of U.S.-based experts in artificial intelligence (AI) and 30 in-depth interviews with experts who participated [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Public and expert predictions for AI‚Äôs next 20 years
entry.summary: We explore how the public and experts anticipate potential positive and negative impacts of AI across key areas of life and society in the coming decades. The post 3. Public and expert predictions for AI‚Äôs next 20 years appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at¬†pewresearch.org/internet. Primary researchers Colleen McClain, Senior ResearcherBrian Kennedy, Senior ResearcherJeffrey Gottfried, Associate Director, Internet and Technology Research¬†Monica Anderson, Director, Internet and Technology Research¬†¬†¬†Giancarlo Pasquini, Research Associate¬† Research team Eileen Yam, Director, Science and Society ResearchAlec [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI
entry.summary: Experts and the public differ in their excitement and worries over AI's increased use, but both share concerns over regulation, misinformation and bias. The post 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI
entry.summary: Experts and the public differ in their excitement and worries over AI's increased use, but both share concerns over regulation, misinformation and bias. The post 2. Views of risks, opportunities and regulation of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Artificial intelligence in daily life: Views and experiences
entry.summary: As AI becomes part of everyday life, we look at how the public and AI experts experience and view AI, including control of its role in their lives. The post 1. Artificial intelligence in daily life: Views and experiences appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence
entry.summary: These groups are far apart in their enthusiasm and predictions for AI, but both want more personal control and worry about too little regulation. The post How the U.S. Public and AI Experts View Artificial Intelligence appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: ‚ÄòEvery piece tells a story‚Äô: Bombs to beauty, from Gaza to Ukraine
entry.summary: What happens to bombs after they land? Some explode. Some don‚Äôt, leaving behind a deadly legacy of war, but now the remnants of conflict and devastation are being turned into wearable messages of peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Armed violence displaces thousands as cholera outbreak worsens
entry.summary: Ongoing violence in North and South Kivu in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) continues to kill, injure and displace civilians, the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Israeli military escalation in Syria, Nicaragua rights probe, South Sudan talks
entry.summary: The UN Special Envoy for Syria has condemned the repeated and intensifying military escalations by Israel in the country, including airstrikes that have caused civilian casualties.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief warns of increasing risk of atrocity crimes in Gaza
entry.summary: The recent killings of 15 medical personnel and humanitarian aid workers in Gaza raise further concerns over the commission of war crimes by the Israeli military, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN envoy urges international support for West Africa and the Sahel
entry.summary: In a briefing to the Security Council on Thursday, the UN Special Representative for West Africa and the Sahel painted a mixed picture of the region, which is facing a growing terrorist threat but also political progress and encouraging initiatives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar: UN chief calls for urgent access as quake toll mounts
entry.summary: The UN chief on Thursday called for immediate and unrestricted humanitarian access to Myanmar, where last week‚Äôs devastating earthquakes claimed over 3,000 lives and left millions in urgent need of aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: AI‚Äôs $4.8 trillion future: UN warns of widening digital divide without urgent action
entry.summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on course to become a $4.8 trillion global market by 2033 ‚Äì roughly the size of Germany‚Äôs economy ‚Äì but unless urgent action is taken, its benefits may remain in the hands of a privileged few, a new UN report warns.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan crisis: UN rights chief condemns extrajudicial killings in Khartoum
entry.summary: The fight for Sudan‚Äôs capital, Khartoum, likely involved widespread summary executions of civilians following its recent recapture by the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), UN human rights chief Volker T√ºrk¬†said¬†on Thursday.

entry.title: Celebrating a Decade of Reveal ‚Äî The Show That Helped Investigative Radio Go Mainstream

entry.title: Who invented s‚Äômores? Forget the myths‚Äîthis is the real history
entry.summary:
Dorothy Christian Moore knew the rules when she climbed in the dark to the ship‚Äôs bridge. ‚ÄúThis is strictly forbidden,‚Äù she wrote as she crossed the Atlantic Ocean, ‚Äúand I hadn‚Äôt been there two minutes before someone seized me roughly from behind.‚Äù She explained to the officer her pursuit of the sunrise, and together they watched the blue horizon split into silver, then blaze to gold‚Äîlike so many campfires that would define her years in the United States.
She arrived the next morning at the invitation of the Girl Scouts to spend the summer of 1923 sharing her skills. Her stint as a volunteer in an officer‚Äôs hospital kitchen during World War I, feeding 150 men a day, had earned her the affectionate nickname ‚ÄúCookie.‚Äù After the war, she continued in public service as a leader in Girl Gu‚Ä¶

entry.title: How these two vitamin supplements could do more harm than good
entry.summary:
Fat-soluble vitamins, such as vitamin E photographed above, are stored in the body's fat reserves, which is why they have potential to accumulate to toxic levels. Fat-soluble vitamins are more likely to cause adverse effects if consumed in large doses. Here‚Äôs what the experts say about vitamin A and E.
Vitamins and supplements are a booming industry. And while there are many important supplements that benefit people with specific deficiencies or certain health conditions, research shows and experts agree that some synthetic vitamins could cause harms such as liver damage, hair loss, joint and muscle pain, and impaired vision.
"Everyone is always searching for that magic pill that will give them great health, but dietary supplements just aren't it because the benefits often don‚Ä¶

entry.title: The 'stork sisters' are saving one of India's largest and rarest birds
entry.summary:
Known locally as¬†hargila, the threatened Greater Adjutant stork has found a champion in an unlikely place: the Harglia Army,¬†a group of about 20,000 rural women in India turned conservationists. Since 2014, the women have worked tirelessly to give the storks a desperately needed reputational revamp.¬†
Once reviled as filthy, adjutants prey on fish, frogs, snakes, rats, and smaller birds like ducks, rummaging through landfills looking for carcasses (hargila translates to bone swallower). Its feeding habits cemented its reputation as unsanitary, a perception that led to a rapid population decline of the adjutant, one of the world‚Äôs largest and rarest storks. Native to¬†India's floodplains in Assam and Bihar, in 2023, it was recently listed as ‚Äúnear threatened‚Äù by the International Union f‚Ä¶

entry.title: Penguins are insanely resilient‚Äîand these explorers are revealing their secrets
entry.summary:
Borboroglu has been an Explorer since receiving the National Geographic/Buffett Award for Leadership in Conservation in 2018. Pablo ‚ÄúPopi‚Äù Garc√≠a Borboroglu and Bertie Gregory have been named the 2025 Rolex National Geographic Explorers of the Year.
As a boy growing up in Argentina‚Äôs Buenos Aires Province, Pablo ‚ÄúPopi‚Äù Garc√≠a Borboroglu was enchanted by his grandmother‚Äôs tales of her youthful visits to the teeming penguin colonies of Argentine Patagonia. He was a 19-year-old tour guide when he first glimpsed one, and it dawned on him then how important it was to share with others his sense of awe, inspiring them to protect penguins and their habitats.¬†
A hemisphere away, Bertie Gregory came to a similar realization as a teenage wildlife photographer roaming the English country‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Florida's greatest family attractions are in the wild
entry.summary:
The observation towers in the Everglades National Park are perfect for taking in Florida's natural beauty. America‚Äôs sunshine state is a natural playground, with wildlife sanctuaries and conservation-led attractions aimed at families.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Families know what to expect from a visit to Florida, right? Disney World, Universal Studios and other theme parks are the main reason for many visits to the southern state. Yet Florida has a lot more to offer kids on a stimulating, active and even educational family holiday. You can snorkel or try Snuba off the coast, kayak through mangrove channels inhabited by manatees, visit the holiday home of one of the world‚Äôs greatest inventors, explore the Everglades swamps, track dolphin‚Ä¶

entry.title: How the simple fork almost tore apart the fabric of society
entry.summary:
The dinner fork is one of the most common fixtures at tables worldwide‚Äîso ordinary, so unthreatening, that few give it a second thought. But for centuries, the fork was condemned as a symbol of decadence, moral decay, and social arrogance.
Throughout most of history, fingers were nature‚Äôs utensils. Knives sliced meat, spoons scooped broth, but only the hand completed the act of nourishment. The fork, however, was something else entirely. ‚ÄúThe introduction of the fork reflected and, at the same time, accelerated a series of profound changes in food culture and table habits,‚Äù says Lucia Galasso, a food anthropologist from Rome. It brought about a more controlled, refined eating process‚Äîone that not everyone welcomed.
The fork‚Äôs journey from forbidden instrument to universal utensil‚Ä¶

entry.title: These sea lions aren't 'demonic'‚Äîthey've been poisoned
entry.summary:
Rescuers capture a sick sea lion in Santa Barbara, California. Hundreds of animals have become ill from a neurotoxin, found in algae blooms, that causes concerning behavioral changes. Two beachgoers have been bitten. A common neurotoxin produced by algae blooms is making California sea lions more aggressive. Here‚Äôs why it has the power to change behavior‚Äîand the danger it poses.
¬†
RJ LaMendola, a 40-year-old photographer, was surfing north of Los Angeles last month when a sea lion charged at him and bit his backside through his wetsuit. The sea lion stalked LaMendola as he desperately tried to paddle to shore, keeping the board between himself and¬†the animal.¬†
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how to describe the fear that gripped me at that moment, staring into the face of this creature tha‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here's why pro photographers obsess over this camera bag
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
For seven years, I relied on my trusty camera bag to accompany me to all the remote places around the world where I reported travel and adventure stories. Last year, it finally broke and I discovered that it had been discontinued. That sent me on an unexpectedly trying mission to find an alternative. There are plenty of camera bags, but as an adventure travel journalist and photographer, I couldn‚Äôt get just any bag.¬†
I needed a weather-resistant ca‚Ä¶

entry.title: Ancient walking trails are back‚Äîand you can hike them
The Louvre is a gastronomic journey‚Äîif you know where to look
In Fiji, these hotels put the guests to work (in a good way)
entry.summary: Tourism Fiji's new initiative is rooted in the local concept of loloma, meaning to act with generosity, driven by love, and aims to inspire visitors to help conserve and protect the local flora and fauna. From mangrove nurseries to manta ray protection, these 6 hotels invite guests to help protect the local land and animals. Fiji‚Äôs gin-bottle-blue waters, luminous sand, and riotously colorful rainforests have long made it a dream destination. But even paradise needs protection ‚Äî the archipelago faces significant threats from climate change, ranging from rising sea levels encroaching on low-lying habitats to coral bleaching damaging the reefs that sustain marine life and shield shorelines from erosion. That‚Äôs why hotels across Fiji are inviting guests to be p‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this the most beautiful bookstore in the world?
entry.summary:
Luigi Frizzo¬†was warned¬†that the property he was about to lease could be in a flood zone because of its proximity to the water and rising sea levels in in Venice, Italy. It actually sparked his decision to name his bookstore¬†Acqua Alta¬†(High Tide).
In addition to coming up with his bookshop's name, Frizzo also took proactive steps to create a flood-proof infrastructure plan to protect¬†more than¬†5,000 books, including first editions published more than a century ago.¬†He decided to store¬†hundreds of books¬†in bathtubs and¬†gondolas,¬†long¬†row boats¬†that have provided transportation through¬†Venice's¬†narrow canals since the 11th century.¬†
In case you didn't know, Acqua Alta¬†is located¬†less than a mile north of Piazza San Marco, the principal public square in Venice. It's easily flooded ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Archaeologists found another Egyptian royal tomb‚Äîbut whose is it?
entry.summary:
The discovery of the tomb of an ancient pharaoh‚Äîthe second report in as many months‚Äîleads a recent spate of archaeological finds from Egypt and casts new light on a formative period of the civilization along the Nile.
In December and January, a team of American and Egyptian archaeologists excavated the roughly 3,600-year-old tomb near the Abydos archaeological site, on the edge of the desert west of the Nile and about 20 miles northwest of the modern city of Luxor in southern Egypt. Egypt's antiquities ministry announced the find in a Facebook post last month.
But the name of the pharaoh who was once entombed there is unknown, as are many of the details about the dynasty of kings he belonged to.
"Egypt was broken apart into multiple rival kingdoms when these kings were rulin‚Ä¶

entry.title: The day that forced Americans to confront a hidden threat
entry.summary:
FBI agents lead Timothy McVeigh from the courthouse after he was charged with the April 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. McVeigh, who was convicted of the bombing that killed 168 people, wasn't a foreign agent but rather a homegrown terrorist with anti-government views. It‚Äôs been 30 years since Timothy McVeigh bombed the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, an attack that reawakened the nation to the dangers of domestic terrorism.
At 9:02 a.m. on April 19, 1995, a bomb ripped open the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City. The explosion took the lives of 168 people, including 19 young children. It would go down as one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in U.S. history.
It also forced Americans to grapple with an uncom‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why you should visit Mississauga‚ÄîCanada's lakeside city
entry.summary:
While Mississauga‚Äôs sleek yet modest skyline and expansive waterfront might not be as well known as the limelight-stealing attractions of neighbouring Toronto, this attractive city on the shores of Lake Ontario has plenty to offer. As home to the country‚Äôs largest airport, it serves as the entry point for many travellers to Canada, but there‚Äôs much to reward visitors who stick around, with more than 500 wildlife-filled parks, an international food scene and Niagara Falls just across the water, plus a vibrant schedule of year-round markets and festivals. Here‚Äôs what not to miss in Mississauga.
In the heart of the city, Riverwood Park‚Äôs 150 acres features curated gardens blooming with rhododendrons, as well as forests, wetlands and meadows hiding herons, sandpipers, hawks, owls an‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to travel in May
entry.summary:
May is the month that signals the start of summer in Europe‚Äôs coastal resorts. Summer is on the way, with Europe's beach resorts dusting off their sun loungers, marine life gathering for feeding seasons and a packed programme of seaside festivals and arts events around the world to tempt travellers.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Temperatures in Mediterranean, Aegean and Ionian waters start to rise, many of the region‚Äôs lidos and beach clubs open, and Ibiza's superclub season gets underway with big launch parties.
There are plenty of seaside arts festivals kicking off, too. Notably Brighton Festival (3-26 May 2025) in the UK ‚Äî a mega multi-arts event taking over the Sussex coastal city, with a programme large enough to warrant its own f‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lebanon: UN expresses deep concern over latest Israeli airstrikes, in call for restraint
entry.summary: The United Nations on Tuesday expressed deep concern over the latest escalation of violence in Lebanon, despite the fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah, following an Israeli airstrike in southern Beirut that reportedly killed four people ‚Äì including a woman ‚Äì and injured several others.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Surging violence as armed groups target civilians in the east, Human Rights Council hears
entry.summary: Civilians continue to bear the brunt of the violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) with 602 victims of extrajudicial or summary executions in North and South Kivu recorded over just two months, the¬†Human Rights Council heard on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan on brink of famine as fighting ravages Darfur, UN warns
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in Sudan is spiralling as rival militaries continue to battle for control of the country, with the UN expressing profound alarm on Monday over escalating hostilities, particularly in North Darfur.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres calls for greater equality and inclusion as world marks Autism Awareness Day
entry.summary: Although people with autism are making enormous contributions to societies across the globe, they still face significant challenges.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN-backed forum seeks to boost resilience of world‚Äôs Least Developed Countries
entry.summary: Policymakers, researchers, the private sector and other stakeholders are meeting in Zambia‚Äôs capital, Lusaka, over the next three days to chart a path toward sustainable development and resilience for the world‚Äôs Least Developed Countries (LDCs).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza aid worker killings: One humanitarian still missing in mass grave
entry.summary: UN humanitarians and partners on Tuesday expressed deep shock at the killing of 15 colleagues on duty in southern Gaza by Israeli forces whose¬†remains were recovered on Sunday from a shallow grave after a week-long rescue operation, noting that one worker is still missing.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar earthquake latest: Entire communities flattened, aid teams say
entry.summary: As the death toll continues to rise in Myanmar after last Friday's earthquake tragedy, UN humanitarians have been rushing to support severely deprived and traumatized victims, warning that the window for lifesaving response is closing.

entry.title: How to save money while traveling
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Travel can be rewarding, but it can also be expensive. The cost can ramp up when you factor in gear and supplies you may need for specialized excursions, like trekking or kayaking. If you do have to shop for an upcoming trip, it pays to be strategic.¬†
‚ÄúBuying affordable, high-quality, multipurpose travel gear means spending less money on products pre-trip,‚Äù says Sunny Fitzgerald, a travel writer who splits her time between Jordan, Costa Rica, and H‚Ä¶
